user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketBind:
```c
int32 OS_SocketBind(osal_id_t sock_id, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_SocketBindAddress(sock_id, Addr);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_SocketListen(sock_id);
        if (return_code == OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE)
        {
            /* This one is OK, it happens if the socket is a datagram/connectionless
             * type that does not need to listen().  For backward compatibility, report
             * success to the caller.
             */
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketBind:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE (-36)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided function and related type/macro definitions for any compiler-specific language extensions (for example: __attribute__, __asm__, __inline__ (compiler-specific spellings), typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, zero-length arrays, flexible array members used in a nonstandard way, GNU extension tokens like __builtin_*, or other vendor-specific keywords). The code uses only standard C constructs: typedefs, integer macros, normal function definition and return, simple if statements, and standard comments. No implementation-specific extension tokens or constructs are present in the displayed fragments, so there are no code fragments that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
